WRITING.TITLE: Midtown Manhattan, New York City. Nikon D850, Nikkor 24-120mm f/4.0

WRITING.TEXT: Having graduated from DX to FX, I am completely floored by the detail the D850 is capable of capturing. The Nikkor 24-120 f/4.0 is a good lens with limitations, which if you keep in mind can do very well. Lens calibration took a bit of time, but zeroed in well enough. Lightroom dehaze, minor sharpening and a bit of a fling with the new texture slider to bring out the chaotic nature of the scene.

WRITING.TITLE: Garment District, New York City. Nikon D850, Sigma 70-200mm f/2.8

WRITING.TEXT: How many rectangles do you see?

I lined it up vertically based on the lower 3 floors. The next two, and the two floors after that, are slightly offset from the ones beneath them. Why? I don #8217;t know. These building were constructed at the beginning of the 20th century and I guess the plumb bob wasn #8217;t invented yet...

An Elevator Door on Sunset Blvd. Los Angeles, California.

WRITING.TEXT: It #8217;s a fine lens. The lens arrangement never seemed to bother me one bit, nor have I ever given it much in the way of thought. One hand on the body, other on the zoom. It #8217;s also very solid, well sealed against the environment, and doesn #8217;t have that billows effect like the Nikon.
TAMRON SP 70-200MM F/2.8. It #8217;s not as easy as the Nikon to calibrate, but it cost half as much.

WRITING.TITLE: My Karen Story
WRITING.TEXT: Through a mutual friend, I have a Karen in my orbit. I would not describe her as a friend, more of an second degree acquaintance if I was pressed. To be honest, she might feel the same way about me. I am a high functioning autistic and can be a bit "opaque" to people who find me a a hard read at much of the time. She has never been favorite company for me as she can kind of loud and boisterous. Sort of a roomy alpha female in any given crowd. She is educated, possessing a masters degree in something from someplace, of which I am not truly interested in finding out about. I know this as she has been known to lecture people about everything from education, politics, medicine, etc to my field (aeronautics) and what they are doing wrong. When contradicted, she will lend force to her opinion with "I have a master's". For all this education, her belief system is all over the map. It's sort of libertarian, facist, new age, pro gun infowars conspiracies, with a side order of junk science. Obama was Kenyan and wants our guns. 9/11 was an inside job. Muslims should be banned from the country. Chemtrails are real. Gluten causes learning disabilities, Essential oils are miracle cures big pharma is hiding from us. When she got wind I was autistic, she cornered me and gave me a lecture about dietary changes and essential oils to cure me of "my condition". She's married, has one son she shares with her present husband, and three step children. The husband is a very easy going guy. Two of the step children are great kids with promising futures. One of the step children is (was... more to follow) a medicated schizophrenic. The child they share between them is an utter mess. It seems the pathology of a Karen is to excuse a problem child with little discipline with anything other than bad parenting. The son is undisciplined, slow witted, socially disengaged, overweight and rude. How rude do you have to be for someone like me to notice. In middle school his mother decided his poor grades, social issues and weight were caused by an undiagnosed gluten allergy and changed his diet. His only real friend was an Xbox which prompted this Karen to announce her son was going to be a professional gamer. I guess that is one way to cover your inability to engage your own child on any meaningful level. By the time he hit highschool, he was morbidly obese, a social outcaste and a failing student. She decided now he had a learning disability, which is possible, decided to homeschool him and treat him with essential oils. She also announced her son was going to be a professional football player. This of course was the latest excuse for obesity and academic disinterest. Homeschooling consisted of slathering him up with oil, then leaving him at home with the Xbox for ten hours a day. The stepson is the real victim here. He's the oldest of the children around 22 years old and developed schizophrenia in his late teens. I have never really met him but I've been told he does well with his medications. The father and biological mother have gone to bat for him and worked hard to get the resources necessary for him to function. For most of his life he lived with his biological mother in Texas, but move in with his father and stepmother when he was 21. This is where schizophrenia meets New Age Google Guru. She somehow got it in her head all his problems were treatable with dietary changes and essential oils. Down the toilet goes the med's and out comes the gluten free diet and essential oils. The medications a schizophrenic takes for their condition is not something you just stop taking. You're on them and you stay on them until a physician says otherwise. The combination of having his meds flushed, served crap food and being rubbed down with fancy cooking oil caused a psychotic break and he beat his mothers face to a pulp. By the time the police got to the house, he was completely canonic. He was hospitalized, placed back on his medication and sent back to Texas. The Karen of our story ended up with multiple surgeries to rebuild her face. I must admit the doctor who is doing the work has some impressive skills. She only has two complaints. 1. She wished she had more time to help her schizophrenic stepson get off the meds with diet, exercise and essential oils to lead a normal life and 2. The medical bills are a fucking bitch. When she said this, I wasn't the only one in the room having issues with eye contact.

I was diagnosed later in life when referred to a psychologist for PTSD related symptoms. When I returned to work, a couple of my coworkers asked how it went to which I replied about the autism diagnosis. They looked at each other, shrugged and turned to me. #8220;We thought you knew... #8221;

I have an engineering degree, which was pushed forward by an interest in physics and math. That being said, I don #8217;t think it has to do with any propensity for math as it does with a willingness to #8220;deep dive #8221; a subject, be it science and mathematic, or Lord of the Rings and Star Wars.
No... this cat found a kid of his very own.
That #8217;s a lot of effort to announce no one will fuck you...

WRITING.TITLE: Underway replenishment operations, Indian Ocean. Canon A-1, Ilford HP5 400
Photo of my Dog. Taken with a Zeh Sport 120 camera, manufactured in Dresden, Germany 1937. I used 120 Ilford HP5.

WRITING.TEXT: One of my hobbies is collected cameras and putting them to use. In this case, I paid around $25.00 in a thrift store near me. It looked to be in working order, so I loaded a roll of Ilford HP5 and used my iPhone as a light meter. Fun fact; the max speed is 100, aperture f/32. You don't realize how much handholding is going on with the new digital cameras today. You really had to know you stuff back then.
Guggenheim...

First, good shot. Second, Not to be a snot, but as a closeted Petrolhead, I feel an unnatural need to point out the Porsche 911 was first produced in 1964. Not that I #8217;m a big fan of the 911. Being rear engined, it suffers dramatically from over steer in a turn. That tail swings like a pendulum.
I agree. A-1 is a great consumer camera. I have had mine since 1982 and it it still going strong. And compared to the AE-1, it #8217;s a tank.

The D7100 is still a workhorse. I #8217;ve got one with three quarters of a million clicks and it #8217;s still cranking. My D850 has a lot to live up to.

WRITING.TITLE: Northern Virginia. Nikon D850. Tamron 70-200mm f/2.8

WRITING.TEXT: D850 with that lens is remarkably fast on the lock on...
When I was 8 years old, my mother confronted me with #8220;do you believe in God?? #8221; I said yes, knowing there was no way I was going to fight that battle and win. In truth, never really did...
The weird part was we were not church going people. Didn #8217;t belong to one, never attended any church functions, outside of someone #8217;s wedding.

My neighbors had two girls who attended the local Montessori school. School uniforms, no makeup or nail polish, etc. Parents weren #8217;t super religious but leaned towards the hardass end of the parental spectrum. I came home between tours in the service and the youngest had turned 19 and Great Jesus Ghost, she was ready for some sinning. We went out for about three months before I had to go back to Europe, but we fractured about 2/3rds of the Commandments. Don #8217;t get me started on the Daddy issues...

From mobile I #8217;ve not experienced this and since I had airdrop #8217;d to to my iPad, I uploaded it from there.

Every autistic has their own superpowers. That being said, how we handle sensory overload differs as much as anyone else. My wife describes mine as collapsing in on myself, then I need about three days home with the shades drawn and noise canceling headphones at the ready.

WRITING.TITLE: Monochrome. Stonehenge, Salisbury, England. Nikon D7100, NIKKOR 28-300mm f/3.5-5.6G
UNDERSTANDING AND SHOOTING IMAGES IN NEF FORMAT
WRITING.TEXT: When I first jumped on the digital photography bandwagon, it was with a bridge style Nikon Coolpix camera. I #8217;m not even sure it was capable of shooting in RAW format, not that I would have understood what it was in the first place. With my first DSLR, I saw this format and thought, considering the money I had laid down, I #8217;d better find out more about this image option. It took a bit of lurking around on the Internet until I found many describing it as a digital negative. Many years later, I think that is over simplistic. A DSLR can be overwhelming when you first look over the options. I still find myself consulting notes and dog eared manuals on changing settings and enabling capabilities. I have been shooting SLR #8217;s since the 1970 #8217;s and understand the trifecta of ISO, shutter, and aperture. White Balance was something you worried about when selecting film. Sharpness was making sure the lens was in focus #8230;. I #8217;m feeling old. So you have dropped anywhere from $500 to $3500 on a DSLR and God bless you. You have in your hands a lot of firepower compared to that 1980 #8217;s Minolta (my second SLR) and you could just go on shooting in auto mode and hope for the best. But you are not going to get the most out of a DSLR unless you are willing to do some research and a bit of trial and error. One of them is taking advantage of the RAW file format proprietary to your camera. Most of the major camera manufactures have their own proprietary format for RAW files. My Nikon used the NEF extension to differentiate it from the JPG file it creates simultaneously. Canon #8217;s extension is CRW, Sony #8217;s extensions can be ARW, SRF or SR2. There is little difference between the extensions really, though there is not much in the way of standardization of RAW files either. Trying to find an overall description of what goes into these files can be problematic. There is no true single format and sometimes each are radically different from other manufactures, to the point of encrypting certain tags to prevent compatibility with third party tools accessing them. Formats from a single manufacture can vary from camera model to camera model. This can be disconcerting for photographers who worry their RAW images might become inaccessible someday, should operating systems change and RAW file formats end up being dropped by the manufacturer. Manufacturers have a tendency to clam up when asked about what goes on inside the camera to produce the RAW files. While all the camera manufacturers provide computer software that can read, duplicate and modify their RAW file formats, third party vendors often have to decipher what is going on and occasionally provide updates to their software to improve compatibility with each of these competing formats. I know Adobe is always sending down updates for RAW file compatibility. Now that I have talked down RAW files, time for me to talk about the benefits of saving your images in RAW format. When you snap that photo, your DSLR has a lot of work to do. First thing it does is decode the image data from the image sensor for compression purposes. Compare the size of a JPG to a TIFF file and you will understand how important this is. Then the camera processor starts looking for defective pixels. This is the same as having a dead pixel on your monitor. Sometimes a pixel might just misfire or go missing. The camera processor identifies these mistakes and then interpolates from nearby pixels as to what is supposed to be there. Most of the time, this is just an error caused by noise. The next photo and the pixel will be fine. Even if it is a dead pixel in the sensor, you #8217;ll never notice as it has been removed by the processor. White balancing is next. I can spend the rest of my life talking about white balance. The processor begins to determine the proper color temperature of the light that was used when the photo was taken. Most of the time, the processor gets it right, but sometimes #8230;.. meh. Now the image is interpolated in a matrix of colored pixels (demosaicing) and filtering followed by noise reduction where there is a trade off between detail and color smoothing through removing small fluctuations in color variations. I don #8217;t like noise reduction, at least at this stage. I think it robs me of image sharpness and usually I turn it off #8230; but I digress. Now the camera processor translates the color from the native color space to the output color space. I like my images in Adobe RGB when I am thinking about hard copy printing. Most people prefer sRBG for viewing on their computer monitors. Both of these are controlled by user settings and it is important to understand these formats. The image is then rendered to the JPG format and for most people that is fine. I set my camera to create both a JPG and a RAW file. In the RAW format, most cameras save these setting in the file, but defer the processing. This leaves some extra, but in many cases, worthwhile work for the photographer. There are many advantages to saving a RAW file. A RAW file has many more shades of color compared to a JPG. Most cameras save the unprocessed image in 12 to 14 bits of color information meaning between 4096 to 16384 shades of color per channel. A higher quality image is also possible thanks to the ability to apply gamma correction, demosaicing, white balance, brightness and contrast before generating RGB pixel values. Some third party programs apply a more accurate method of constructing the final image from the setting and RAW format than the camera might be capable of. You can also determine the color space. sRBG for the Internet or Adobe RGB for printing. And here is what makes them all the more important to me; changes to the RAW file are non-destrucatable. By saving the file or converting it to JPG or TIFF, you have not altered the RAW file. If later you decide you need it in a different color space for printing, or the white balance is just a bit off, the RAW file is still ready for you to modify or reset and start again. I have sat on RAW files for years waiting for a Photoshop plugin or technique to show itself to save a RAW file from the delete key. There are a few drawbacks to using RAW files. The most obvious is the size of the file, which can be as much as 6 times the size of a JPG. That means less photos on a SD card. Then, as mentioned before, there is no accepted standard between camera manufactures as far as format, though DNG is gaining some ground, but acceptance is being slowed by pushback from manufacturers. Finally workflow. Processing RAW files can slow down editing of images considerably, though some software allows for batch processing and syncing of changes among several images at a time. This is the case for Adobe Lightroom. So, I guess the point of this article is #8220;if you have it, use it. #8221;

My wife and I left London very early in the morning for Salisbury to avoid congestion and ended up at Stonehenge just as it was opening. This was very fortunate as I was able to get an image before a measurable fraction of the European Union showed up to clog up the pathway around the site. I decided on my composition then stood there for easily 20 min waiting for a few tourist to exit the frame before doing the capture. There were still a few of my fellow travelers in the image, but I was confident I could remove them in post. Shooting in Britain is hit and miss. Even in the fairer months, you get about two weeks of rain on average. I already knew this was going to be monochrome as the lighting was flat. I also didn't want another trite Stonehenge photo to match the 20,000 images already out there. I first edited the NEF File in Photoshop to remove a few bodies, as well as a low lying rope barrier used to keep visitors off the henge proper. In Lightroom, I set up the initial monochrome tonal range. I didn't use a red filter as I disagree with how it is implemented by Adobe. I then added a top and bottom graduated exposurer. After this, a few more tweaks and applied a printer profile for output. * As HDR would have been interesting as well as provide an additional image to work with, but you are forbidden to use a tripod around areas like this.
No, not really...
I just unloaded a roll of 120 film from my Mamiya C330 Professional. They shall never know the pain. #128406;

Yeah, I jumped a step. I always import into Lightroom, then right click to edit in Photoshop. This creates a TIF file which I edited out the bodies. I start out in Lightroom so much, I often forget PS is a separate program altogether. I do recommend you use TIF files rather than JPG as there is an enormous amount of information in comparison.
I have an Agfa Ansco PD16 Plenax from the 1930 #8217;s I repaired, then modified to 120 film. I shoot it now and again for the retro effect, but it reminds me how good we have it now...

Yeah... that #8217;s not a plus. DNG file lack significant metadata such as Active D-Lighting, Picture Controls, Focus Point, etc. Because of the that, many common post-processing software packages out there either do not read DNG at all, or read it poorly, making DNG a lot less useful than it was designed to be in the first place.

WRITING.TEXT: The Crow is the bird on the arm. The first three enlisted ranks are simple hash marks . When you make petty officer, you get the bird ( Crow) and the red chevron.
